column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	235	On behalf of the Institute of Professional Auctioneers and Valuers

column3: I thank the Chairman and the members for the opportunity to make this short presentation to them on our priorities for budget 2015.  By way of background

column5: 000 auctioneers and valuers nationwide.  Founded in 1971
column6: the institute’s main aim is to promote the highest professional standards among members at all times.  As we stated in the submission
column7: IPAV believes that a properly functioning housing and mortgage market is essential for a properly functioning economy and a stable society.  Most observers
column8: including ourselves
column9: believe that the industry is now beginning to experience a modest improvement
column10: although there are signs of many tiers beginning to emerge.  Central to making the market stable and sustainable is a proper and adequate supply of new housing
column11: and that should be the Government’s main priority for the property industry.  Incentives to purchase are of little use if there is not an adequate supply.  The Forfás report on Ireland’s construction sector and Construction 2020

column1: both offer a number of worthwhile ideas and aims

The lack of such advice was a prime cause of the property boom and bust
column3: and immediate steps should be taken to ensure that never happens again.  It is important to have a body of such experts on hand to identify and address problems and provide advice and guidelines to policy makers.

column1: Demand for housing is at an all time high in Dublin’s inner city yet it is estimated that between the canals there are approximately 155 acres of land and some 300 vacant sites that could be used for building residential and commercial property. column2: the introduction of a vacant site levy in budget 2015 would propel this drive to increase the supply of housing in areas where it is most needed.

column1: Regarding NAMA property sales

column3: IPAV believes it now makes sense to sell these units individually or in small lots.  That would have the double advantage of securing more money per unit for the Exchequer and give young people and investors the opportunity to buy directly from NAMA

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	236	I thank the Chairman and the committee for inviting us to appear before them today.  As the Simon Communities in Ireland
column2: Focus Ireland and Threshold are working to tackle homelessness and the housing crisis
column3: we have agreed to share our time to be more informative and useful but also to avoid repetition for the members.  I will set the scene briefly
column4: examine some of the solutions and then hand over to Mr. Mike Allen from Focus Ireland and Mr. Bob Jordan from Threshold.  As everybody is aware
column5: we are in the middle of a homelessness and housing crisis.  More people are at risk of homelessness
column6: more people are becoming homeless
column7: and more people than ever are turning to services for support.  The Simon Communities of Ireland has reported a 24% increase in the number of people turning to our services in our most recent annual report
column8: and the numbers continue to grow.  There are approximately 90
column9: 000 households on the social housing waiting lists.  Rents have increased by about 9% nationally and at different amounts in terms of urban centres; it is about 14% in Dublin.  The number of properties available to rent has declined sharply to just under 6
column10: 000 properties on 1 May this year.  Rent supplement levels are proving insufficient to meet the cost of many rental properties.  With this lack of available social housing and barriers preventing people accessing houses in the private rental sector
column11: it has become much more difficult for people to secure affordable and appropriate accommodation.  That is not just causing homelessness.  It is also preventing people leaving homelessness
column12: with people who are homeless effectively trapped in emergency accommodation for far longer than is appropriate.  Cutbacks to funding for housing support
column13: health services
column15: education and training
column17: have knock-on effects that contribute to homelessness.  That combination of factors can trigger homelessness in the first place but can also prevent people moving out of homelessness because they do not have the necessary support.  It is clear that austerity budget measures are having the biggest impact on the people who are the most vulnerable.  A significant policy shift is required to address the growing social housing and income adequacy needs.  The reliance on the private sector to provide social housing only has demonstrably failed.  We need sustainable investment in social housing and a large provision in the private rented sector.  That needs vision
column19: political will and commitment on the part of practitioners and providers to deliver quality social housing but it also needs to be resourced.  It is in this context that the Government has committed to ending long-term homelessness and rough sleeping by 2016 using a housing-led approach.  Housing-led approaches are extremely effective in addressing and ending homelessness for good.  That is Government policy
column20: and we wholeheartedly support this approach
column21: but housing-led approaches are also predicated on the availability of support appropriate to each person's needs.  That might be support to live independently with regard to cookery skills
column22: budgeting and tackling loneliness and isolation but for some people it also means helping them to address mental health issues
column24: and drug and alcohol issues.    Resources must allow for the diversity of needs but also the fluctuation in needs.  For example
column25: if somebody reaches a mental health crisis it is vitally important that the level and intensity of support can be increased just for that period to help them get through the crisis and remain in their tenancy.  The level of support can then roll down once the crisis has ended.  It is clear that ending homelessness requires more than just housing
column26: but housing is a central piece of this jigsaw and remains the single greatest barrier to implementing a housing-led approach. The Government must reappraise the upfront investment required to generate the flow of accommodation that
column28: will enable people who have been homeless to take up sustainable housing options. column29: be it housing or income difficulties.  We need to find more options and better
column30: more sustainable ways to house people in the longer term.  Critical to that is preventing people becoming homeless
column31: and then supporting people to make the smooth transition out of emergency accommodation to independent living.  Crucial elements to achieving this are income adequacy
column34: and health and social care supports.  The Department of the Environment
column36: the Department of Social Protection and the Health Service Executive
column38: play a vital role in ensuring access to housing
column40: and the critical support services that offer the most effective means both of preventing homelessness but also supporting people to move out of homelessness.  To address this housing and homeless crisis
column41: we urgently need access to housing and access to support in housing
column42: but also action to prevent homelessness and the recurrence of homelessness.  We urge the members to support us in our call to ensure that the Government takes on these issues in budget 2015.

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	328	The construction cost of houses in Ireland has been very expensive in recent years
column2: right through the recession and right up to date.  It is something that is mystifying.  If one is looking at a survey
column3: most auctioneers would look at a survey of three-bedroom properties
column4: because they are to be found throughout the country
column5: be it in Sligo
column6: Dublin
column7: Galway
column8: Mullingar or wherever.  The price
column9: value and cost to build such a property in 2006 would be anything from €70 to €100 per square foot.  That price has not changed today.  Moreover
column10: this is not due to wages in total but to the actual cost of the products one uses
column11: which appear not to have reduced at all.  That building cost is there and it remains quite high.  I acknowledge that much of the value and price of property in 2006 was way above builders' profit on top of the actual cost of building houses.  At present however
column12: if for example one takes a three-bedroom semi-detached house in Longford
column13: for which one might get €60
column16: there is no way in which a builder could build one of those houses for that sort of money.  Until such time as builders can build properties and get a reasonable amount of money for what they build
column17: such properties will not be built.  Consequently
column18: what will happen one day is that when the existing stock of property runs out
column19: the property market will move on quite rapidly and its price will move considerably.

One could sell a three-bedroom semi-detached house for €70
column2: 000 throughout the country - I do not refer to the city - because there is a many-tiered market in the country.  Even towns on their own-----

column1: #CiaranLynch	unknown-#CiaranLynch-party	unknown-#CiaranLynch-dob	unknown-#CiaranLynch-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	331	Let us speak straight
column2: as that is a case of supply and demand.  We have houses in Roscommon and my research on this matter shows that back in 2006 and 2007
column3: we were building 60% more houses than actually were required by the market.  Moreover
column4: we also were building them in the wrong places.  In cities such as Cork
column5: Limerick and Dublin
column6: there is no vacant build such as exists elsewhere and what is needed is for such vacant build to come into the market.  However
column7: I believe Senator Barrett's point concerns the scenario in which we were to return to prudential lending and to apply what Mr. Davitt was saying about loan-to-value and all the rest.  Incidentally
column8: I understand his model because I looked at it quite extensively.  This was done by Genworth in Canada
column9: where a property bubble was avoided because they triangulated the purchasing of houses.  The insurance company would not allow one to buy a house that was overvalued by a bank because it would be underwriting it.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	332	I called for some of this.

column2: the question Senator Barrett is asking is very simple.  It does not matter whether one is living in Leitrim
column3: Cork
column4: Dublin
column5: Donegal or anywhere else.  One simply takes the national industrial wage and applies it to that area in the country.  The committee heard disputes on figures yesterday
column6: when IBEC and others appeared before the joint committee
column7: stating the national industrial wage is either €36
column9: 000.  Let us split the difference and make it €40
column10: 000.  Prudential lending practices will state that four times the national industrial wage will be €160
column11: 000.  If one operates on the basis of a loan-to-value rate of 90% and all the rest

column13: this means that a standard three-bedroom house for an entry couple must be somewhere around €160
column15: Mr. Davitt is suggesting the existing business model in the construction industry cannot build a house for €160
column16: 000.  There is something radically wrong if prudential lending suggests such a figure but the industry is unable to produce the product at or below that figure.

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	334	They can do so in respect of basic three-bedroom semi-detached houses.  They can produce three-bedroom semi-detached houses in most parts of the country
column2: depending on the value and price of the site because that is where it all starts
column3: as well as levies imposed by the county councils to go with it.  Before one begins to build
column4: one obviously must buy the site and must put in place levies and everything else.  However
column5: even at that
column6: I believe one can build such houses for between €100
column8: 000.  The Chairman is correct in that it is a case of supply and demand.  It is not in the interests of auctioneers that the price of property runs up because we must sell the property whether it is high or low.  That is our job and we are not-----

column1: #CiaranLynch	unknown-#CiaranLynch-party	unknown-#CiaranLynch-dob	unknown-#CiaranLynch-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	335	Mr. Davitt is suggesting that a potential bubble is coming down the line.  My response to is to ask how can there be a potential bubble
column2: if one maintains prudential lending practices?  This bottle I have to hand can be worth as anybody is willing to pay for it.  However
column3: were the bank to tell me it can only give me three times my income to buy this bottle
column4: so doing would contain the market.  Consequently
column5: how can we have a property bubble if the banks do what they should have been doing over the last couple of years?

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	336	I am not saying there is a property bubble coming down the line.  I actually am saying the opposite
column2: which is that when supply of the property that currently is available has all gone
column3: people must then adjust to a situation of reality
column4: in which builders must build properties at a price at which they can afford to build them.  If I sell a three-bedroom semi-detached property today in Roscommon for instance and I get €80
column5: 000 for it but if a builder down the road cannot build a house for less than €120
column7: the next house to be sold after the last house is sold at €80
column8: 000 will be priced at €120
column9: 000.  This is not a property bubble but is a property price that is matched to the price for which the builders actually are building the properties.  While people talk about property bubble in Dublin
column10: it is not a property bubble but is a property spike.  This property spike exists obviously because of supply and demand and the money is available at present.  I believe a property bubble will only come into place when it is all being done on finance.

column1: #SeanDBarrett	unknown-#SeanDBarrett-party	unknown-#SeanDBarrett-dob	unknown-#SeanDBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	337	Why then

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	338	The costs are there.  The cost of a site is there and we could easily stretch out these costs

column3: I can tell the Senator that amazingly
column4: the cost of building the houses has not changed.  Nobody can understand why the costs have not changed because if one takes one particular component
column5: such as for instance laying blocks
column6: people who were building a block house in the good times in 2006 could have been paying between €1.10 and €1.15 to build a block and are now probably paying €0.60.The wages have come down to a certain degree but the actual cost of building the houses has not come down greatly. It should have come down to match but it has not done that and we are aware of that fact.

column1: #SeanDBarrett	unknown-#SeanDBarrett-party	unknown-#SeanDBarrett-dob	unknown-#SeanDBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	339	Senator Hayden is always raising the NAMA stock in the Seanad.  We have the numbers.  A total of 5

column1: #	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	340	I and most auctioneers believe that if all the properties the banks hold at the moment are put on the market
column2: property will find its own level and properties will be sold regardless of whether one is in Roscommon or Dublin.  If there are many properties in Roscommon and they have to be sold at €30
column5: there is a value for those properties and we believe there are people out there to buy them.  Until such time as those properties are put on the market

column7: NAMA and the banks are holding off so many properties and we hear about all these buy-to-let properties that are not being put up for sale because they are afraid they will flood the market. column8: we should see where the property market is in building properties and rebuilding new properties to see where we go from there.  We do not see any point in agencies like NAMA holding these properties and NAMA selling massive amounts of properties to international buyers who
column9: in turn
column10: will sell them to Irish people two or three years down the line and inflate the price of the properties.  We do not see any reason for that. column12: 000 because that is the market price today

#	unknown-#-party	unknown-#-dob	unknown-#-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	343	There was a big question about the offer from NAMA of social housing not being taken up by local authorities.  That process is quite non-transparent so it is quite hard to give an answer.  From the extent to which we are able to see what is going on
column2: a number of those units are being offered.  For example
column3: we have had a lot of State investment to move away from having large concentrations of social housing in one place and to create multi-use and mixed communities.  A number of the units that were being offered around the country were right beside or adjacent to existing areas of concentrated social housing or were built to a standard which the local authorities thought was suitable for selling to the private market but if which
column4: if they were in their ownership
column5: would result in extremely high maintenance costs.  Both those decisions by local authorities to turn those down
column6: to the extent that they are true and I do not know whether they explain the whole thing or not
column7: are perfectly rational decisions.  It is reasonable that local authorities should not be taking into public ownership large tranches of poorly built housing right beside existing high levels of social deprivation because we would be building problems for the future.  While we want a clearer and faster process
column8: I would be wary about putting pressure on local authorities higgledy piggledy just to accept these units.  Due to the fact that there is some development
column9: partly through NAMA
column10: of half-finished estates and so on
column11: areas where local authorities were previously turning down units for social housing because of the high density of social housing use are now beginning to pick up in terms of owner-occupiers so if the local authorities take them up
column12: they would be mixed tenure areas.  That is opening up opportunities for some of these units which were correctly turned down before but which might be worth revisiting.  I think that the Department has asked that they be revisited.

column1: #SeanDBarrett	unknown-#SeanDBarrett-party	unknown-#SeanDBarrett-dob	unknown-#SeanDBarrett-constituency	speech	unkown-language	2014-07-16 00:00:00	Pre-Budget Submissions: Discussion (Resumed)	344	I think houses were sold recently in Tuam for €20
